review.title: Detection Algorithms for Communication Systems Using Deep Learning
review.abstract: The design and analysis of communication systems typically rely on the development of mathematical models that describe the underlying communication channel, which dictates the relationship between the transmitted and the received signals. However, in some systems, such as molecular communication systems where chemical signals are used for transfer of information, it is not possible to accurately model this relationship. In these scenarios, because of the lack of mathematical channel models, a completely new approach to design and analysis is required. In this work, we focus on one important aspect of communication systems, the detection algorithms, and demonstrate that by borrowing tools from deep learning, it is possible to train detectors that perform well, without any knowledge of the underlying channel models. We evaluate these algorithms using experimental data that is collected by a chemical communication platform, where the channel model is unknown and difficult to model analytically. We show that deep learning algorithms perform significantly better than a simple detector that was used in previous works, which also did not assume any knowledge of the channel.

metadata.title: Detection Algorithms for Communication Systems Using Deep Learning

sections.heading: 1 Introduction

sections.heading: 2 Problem Statement
sections.text: In a digital communication system, a message is converted into a sequence of transmission symbols representing different transmission signals.

sections.heading: 3 Detection Using Deep Learning
sections.text: It is the first phase in which known sequences of transmission symbols are repeated and received by the system to generate a series of training data.

sections.heading: 3.1 Symbol-by-Symbol Detection
sections.text: The most basic neural network architecture that can be used for detection uses multiple dense neural network layers, followed by a final softmax layer [7, 8]. In this network, the ith layer is byoi = f (Wioi − 1 + bi), (8) where f () is the activation function, Wi and bi are the weight and bias parameters, and oi is the output of the ith layer. Input into the first layer is the received signal yk or the feature vector rk, which is selectively extracted from the received signal by pre-processing. Output of the last layer is the length m (i.e. the cardinality is the symbol set), and the activation function for the last layer is the softmax activation, the byctui (z) = ezi-j e zj. sections.heading: 3.2 Sequence Detection
sections.text: In this case it is possible that the following way (Wy, fyk + Wa, fak − 1 + Wc, fck − 1 + bf), (12) ck = fk ck − 1 + ik tanh (Wy, cyk + Wa), cak − 1 + bc, (13) uk = 1 (Wy, uyk − 1 + Wc, uak − 1 + Wc), (14) ak tanh (15), where the elementary vector (Wa, uyk + Wa) uk = 1 (Wa, uak − 1 + Wc, uak − b), (14) ak − (14) ak = uk tanh (15).

sections.heading: 4 Experimental Setup
sections.text: This year, it is as far as ever in the history of the city, where it is as far as never before in the history of the city.

sections.heading: 5 Results
sections.text: We use our experimental platform to collect measurement data and to create the dataset used for training and testing detection algorithms. Specifically, as explained in the previous section, four symbol intervals of 250 ms, 334 ms, 380 ms and 500 ms are considered to be the results used in data rates of 2 to 4 bits per second (bps). For each symbol interval, random bit sequences of length 120 are used, with each of the 100 transmissions separated at times, resulting in 12k bits per symbol interval used for training and testing. From the data, 84 transmissions per symbol interval (10,080 bits) are used for training and 16 transmissions used for testing (1,920 bits). Therefore, the total number of training bits used for testing is 40,320, and the total number of bits used for testing is 7,680.We start by using the detection rate of the change in pH.

sections.heading: 6 Conclusions
sections.text: These algorithms have a lot of potential in systems where the underlying physical models of the channel are unknown or inaccurate. For example, molecular communication, which has many potential applications in medicine, is very difficult to model with detectable analytical models. We are using an experimental platform that simulates chemical communication within a container to collect experimental data for training and testing deep learning algorithms. We are showing that deep learning sequence detectors can significantly improve detection performance compared to a basic approach that is also not based on channel models. This shows the promising performance that deep learning detection algorithms may have in designing future communication systems. Some interesting open problems that we would like to investigate in the future are: First, we want to perform more parameter tuning to find better neural networks for detection. Another important problem that we want to investigate is how quickly learning systems will be able to change the concentration of detectors, for example, if the network becomes resilient to alep systems.

metadata.abstractText: The design and analysis of communication systems typically rely on the development of mathematical models that describe the underlying communication channel, which dictates the relationship between the transmitted and the received signals. However, in some systems, such as molecular communication systems where chemical signals are used for transfer of information, it is not possible to accurately model this relationship. In these scenarios, because of the lack of mathematical channel models, a completely new approach to design and analysis is required. In this work, we focus on one important aspect of communication systems, the detection algorithms, and demonstrate that by borrowing tools from deep learning, it is possible to train detectors that perform well, without any knowledge of the underlying channel models. We evaluate these algorithms using experimental data that is collected by a chemical communication platform, where the channel model is unknown and difficult to model analytically. We show that deep learning algorithms perform significantly better than a simple detector that was used in previous works, which also did not assume any knowledge of the channel.
